text: when science writer Jackson Landrus
started studying black widow spiders his
interest was more than academic he had
discovered a host of them living around
his front yard in central Virginia but
little did he expect that one of those
spiders would almost get the better of
him
Jackson Landers writes about his
experience on the cover of science times
this week and he joins us now to talk
about it
Jackson Landers welcome well thanks for
having me David so what is a black widow
spider exactly the black widow is a well
there is there's actually a whole group
of species but usually what we're
talking about is a southern black widow
it is a spider with a very distinctive
graceful black form the mature females
are black and they have typically a red
hourglass on the bottom so it's a very
striking looking spider and it's it's
one of the few venomous of spiders in
North America that you really have to
worry about we've got thousands of
different types of spiders in North
America and most of them you know you
just let them go about their business
but the black widow is it's the one you
have to really look out for in the
eastern US
why does so few people get bitten I
think that um the black widow even
though it is it's deadly it doesn't
really want to seek a conflict you know
they're actually very I found that they
were actually very hesitant to use their
venom I actually had a widow in a jar
that dumb with a captive on my desk for
most of last winter I want to feed it
little crickets and moths and things and
I would watch when I would drop an
insect in for her to eat I noticed that
she wouldn't she was a little bit shy of
it even though this was something that
was clearly food it's a cricket it's not
even a human being she'd back away from
it look at it for a little while and
then she'd come in and she still
wouldn't give it to venom she would
approach it backwards and and wrap it up
in silk and then the last thing that she
would do would be to inject the venom so
their their first instinct is to retreat
and avoid an account and encounter I
mean if a black widow bites you it's
probably because it's about to be squish
it's it's going to be a lot better off
just kind of moving out of the way and
this is you you found this out
through first-hand experience tell us
what happens I did boy I almost had it
coming because I knew that there were
black widows are there on this porch I
had killed so many of them right there
and so one day I was I'd been riding all
day Edmund working and aside I was going
to go to my favorite fishing hole to
catch dinner and so I grabbed my I
grabbed the shoes off the porch three
feet away from where I had wiped out a
whole egg sack of black widows a few
months earlier and I put that in my
fishing gear in the car I drove to my
spot I got out of the car I pulled on
the aqua socks and I took a few steps
towards my fishing hole and I felt
something it was like a bee sting
right as I I walked down and sat down on
a rock and I took off the UM I took off
the shoe when I looked at the bite it
was just these two tiny little pinpricks
I knew it was too pinprick something it
bit me I knew it wasn't a stinger and
the symptoms progressed unlike anything
else it what really after about 15
minutes I could tell this definitely
wasn't a bee sting I felt a warmth in my
abdomen and it was first was sort of a
tickle and got warmer and warmer and
then that turned into a kind of cramping
and when the cramping started that was
when I knew I had to get out of here I
had to I had to get home or get
somewhere where I could um where I
wouldn't just be laying in an agony you
know by the water and I think by the
time I checked into the ER I had to be
put in a in a wheelchair and they
weren't going to be able to give me any
kind of long duration pain medication
they weren't going to be able to give me
because what the venom is doing is
causing pain it's causing muscle spams
muscle spasms and cramps what should
somebody do who suspects he or she has
been bitten by by a black widow have
someone take you to the hospital
Jackson Landers is a science writer and
the author of a number of books
including one called eating aliens can't
wait to read that one Jackson Landers
thanks for coming in to talk about your
experience
you
